messageBody:
My apologies if this has already been covered, but Yahoo's search
functionality for this list is giving me some sort of Python error,
and I don't much feel like clicking "Back" through 1500 messages and
looking for relevant messages. :)

Before I came across JUnit, I typically did unit testing with
the main() method of a class. I expect that's a fairly common idiom
around here, but I added a small twist to make my life easier. Suppose
I have some class Foo which I want to add a relatively comprehensive
testing suite to. Instead of adding a main() to Foo, and the
appropriate helper methods to set up, run, and tear down tests, I'd
create a static inner class, called Test, and put all the testing
material in there.

I figure this idea has several advantages over other possible
approaches:
1. One can package up the code for public release by removing all
files that end in *Test.class.
2. Code for the test suite is in the same file as the code it
tests. This makes it easy to add new tests.
3. There's a clear distinction between what methods are part of the
testing suite and what methods are part of the actual implementation
of the class.

Of course, I'd rather switch over to JUnit, for many reasons, but have
found so far that this idea doesn't cross over very well. Here's what
I've tried, and the errors I've gotten; if anyone has any insight on
what I can do, please let me know.

public class SomeClass {
// actual code goes here...

public class Test extends TestCase {
public Test(String name) {
super(name);
}

public void testSomething {
assertEquals(true, true);
}
}
}

public class ComprehensiveTestSuite {
public static void main (String[] args) {
junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
}

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite result = new TestSuite();
result.addTestSuite(SomeClass$Test.class);
return result;
}
}

This compiles fine, but I get the following error if I run, say,
java ComprehensiveTestSuite:

.F
Time: 0.096
There was 1 failure:
1)
warning(junit.framework.TestSuite$1)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:
Class SomeClass$Test has no public constructor TestCase(String name)
at
ComprehensiveTestSuite.main(ComprehensiveTestSuite.java:7)

FAILURES!!!
Tests run: 1, Failures: 1, Errors: 0

Any ideas? Thanks a lot. (I'm using JDK1.3 and JUnit 3.7, by the way.)

- Colin McMillen
